Global economy braces for Trump's trade war and its consequences
subhead: After three months of tumultuous negotiations, the US is preparing to unveil trade agreements with its main partner countries by July 9. But the announcement of tariff hikes, followed by numerous reversals, has already begun to undermine the foundations of global growth.

France faces 'significant delays' in meeting 2050 carbon neutrality target
subhead: In its annual report, the High Council for Climate warns that the pace of decarbonization 'slowed considerably' in 2024 and laments the rollback of environmental measures, such as low-emission zones and the zero net land artificialization target.

title: French air traffic controllers' strike affects thousands of travelers
subhead: Tens of thousands of passengers across Europe were affected as French air traffic controllers launched a two-day strike on Thursday, July 3, to protest against understaffing and "toxic management." With the summer holiday season about to get underway, budget airline Ryanair said it was forced to cancel 170 flights, affecting 30,000 passengers.

title: The invisible transformation of Wimbledon's grass
subhead: Long dominated by serve-and-volley enthusiasts, the London tournament opted for a more resistant grass in 2001, which lengthened rallies and allowed less offensive players to dominate, including Carlos Alcaraz and Novak Djokovic.

title: Water shortages in the upper Indian Himalayas are causing 'villages to die out and traditions to disappear'
subhead: 'The Himalayas Overheating'  (4/6). Zanskar, located in the Ladakh region of India's mountain highlands, has felt the full force of glacier retreat. With no access to water, villagers have been abandoning their homes and traditional way of life.
byline: By Sophie Landrin (Padum (Ladakh, India) special correspondent)

title: Anne Deysine, US law expert: 'We are experiencing the dawn of a lawless society'
subhead: In an interview, Anne Deysine, a US law specialist, explains that the US Supreme Court's June 27 ruling would lead to institutional 'chaos,' as Trump is now able to keep changing US institutions and society through his executive orders, which are often illegal.

title: In Japan, a manga artist has predicted a disaster in early July, causing a drop in tourism
subhead: The 'prediction' made by a manga author has sparked panic and a decline in bookings around July 5, the day that she claims an earthquake will trigger a massive tsunami. Authorities have reiterated that it is impossible to predict earthquakes.

title: French foreign minister on Iran's nuclear program: 'It is essential that our security interests be taken into account'
